subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Review charts for Shavian Quikscript Extensions
msgSnippet: ... Point taken.  I guess my confusion arose when I was thinking that Shavian and QuickScript are essentially both English... but in fact even mixing TO and QS
messageBody:
On Thu 2007.11.01, at 12:02, Michael Everson wrote:
Yes, but the same is true if you have Serbian in Cyrillic or Latin
script. I assume that you would use a script tag in some way to get
the Serbian read out correctly. If that were the case...

>Would it be possible in that case to have both scripts on the same page?

... then it does seem that Shaw might be supplemented by a Shqw which
the text reader would have to be able to parse. Ranges tagged en_Shaw
and ranges tagged en_Shqw would invoke different speech modules.

Right, John? I mean... I'm not sure I can get the Mac OS for instance
to read anything but English at present.

Point taken.  I guess my confusion arose when I was thinking that Shavian and QuickScript are essentially both English... but in fact even mixing TO and QS on a page would be likely to confuse a text-to-speech system, to the point of requiring extra markup.

In that case, I don't really have any issues with combining those two character points.  (And perhaps Shavian thigh with QS fee?  Depending on the font these can look very similar.)

On the other hand, I think the draft you posted is just fine.  Eliminating two characters will only get us down to 26 characters, which would probably still be a 32-point block with more un-encoded slots.

oliver

> Yes, but the same is true if you have Serbian in Cyrillic or Latin
> script. I assume that you would use a script tag in some way to get
> the Serbian read out correctly. If that were the case...
>
> >Would it be possible in that case to have both scripts on the same  
> page?
>
> ... then it does seem that Shaw might be supplemented by a Shqw which
> the text reader would have to be able to parse. Ranges tagged en_Shaw
> and ranges tagged en_Shqw would invoke different speech modules.
>
> Right, John? I mean... I'm not sure I can get the Mac OS for instance
> to read anything but English at present.

Point taken.  I guess my confusion arose when I was thinking that  
Shavian and QuickScript are essentially both English... but in fact  
even mixing TO and QS on a page would be likely to confuse a text-to- 
speech system, to the point of requiring extra markup.

In that case, I don't really have any issues with combining those two  
character points.  (And perhaps Shavian thigh with QS fee?  Depending  
on the font these can look very similar.)

On the other hand, I think the draft you posted is just fine.   
Eliminating two characters will only get us down to 26 characters,  
which would probably still be a 32-point block with more un-encoded  
slots.

oliver
